content: In the following questions, I will provide a target Python program code. The code is a program containing a loop, and the purpose of the code is indicated by its function name. Please provide a loop invariant for the i-th iteration of the loop to prove the partial correctness of the program. The loop invariant should be written in the form 'xxx_value = fun(arr[xxx]->arr[xxx])'. (Please note that your answer should only contain statements in the specified format without any additional text.)(Notice that for the same program, if the loop is changed to iterate from the end to the beginning, the array index in the loop invariant should be adjusted to the latter part.)

def give_last(arr):
    last_value = arr[0]
    s = 0
    while s < len(arr):
        last_value = arr[s]
        s += 1
    return last_value

The loop invariant for the i-th iteration of the loop in the provided program is:


```less
last_value_i = fun(arr[i]->arr[i])
```
where `last_value_i` is the value of the last element in the array after the i-th iteration of the loop.

The invariant ensures that the loop maintains the correct state as it iterates through the array. It ensures that each time the loop iterates, it correctly updates `last_value` with the last element in the array.

The invariant also ensures that the last element in the array is returned at the end of the loop, as specified by the function `give_last`.

Note that this invariant assumes that `fun(arr[i]->arr[i])` correctly computes the last element in the array for each iteration of the loop. It is up to you to provide an appropriate definition of `fun` that fulfills this requirement.

def give_first(arr):
    first_value = arr[-1]
    s = len(arr)
    while s > 0:
        s -= 1
        first_value = arr[s]
    return first_value

The loop invariant for the i-th iteration of the loop in the provided program is:


```less
first_value_i = fun(arr[-i-1]->arr[-i])
```
where `first_value_i` is the value of the first element in the array after the i-th iteration of the loop.

This invariant ensures that the loop maintains the correct state as it iterates through the array. It ensures that each time the loop iterates, it correctly updates `first_value` with the first element in the array.

The invariant also ensures that the first element in the array is returned at the end of the loop, as specified by the function `give_first`.

Note that this invariant assumes that `fun(arr[-i-1]->arr[-i])` correctly computes the first element in the array for each iteration of the loop. It is up to you to provide an appropriate definition of `fun` that fulfills this requirement.
